awd_titl_txt: IRES Track 1 IRTG Engaged in Dissecting and Reengineering the Regulatory Genome
awd_abstract_narration:
Much of the highly impactful research in genome sciences over the past two decades has come from of international, interdisciplinary projects. This project establishes a program to help prepare the next generation of leaders in genome sciences to be interdisciplinary researchers with experience in collaborative, international research. The program builds on strong existing ties between Duke University and four Berlin institutions led by Humboldt University, and on a history of productive collaboration between several of the faculty who will carry out the training. The centerpiece of the program involves 2-3 month-long visits by graduate students from Duke University to host lab groups in Berlin. The goal of these visits is to embed students in a lab group that provides exposure to complementary conceptual and technical approaches and, equally, to provide experience in working as part of a team-based, international research project. Funding for a complementary program on the German side was recently awarded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG), providing a fully reciprocal exchange program. Students will not only benefit from the advantage of combined physical and human resources that this program provides, they will gain valuable methodological skills, domain expertise, and experience in critical thinking through a truly collaborative learning and research environment. Our long-term goal is to help them become future leaders in the ongoing transformation of biology into a quantitative discipline, with a long-term impact on how genomics affects numerous aspects of human life.

The program described in this proposal establishes an international collaboration between Duke University and four Berlin institutions (led by Humboldt University) that will offer U.S. graduate students an unparalleled opportunity to obtain a quantitative understanding of genome function and gene regulation within the context of biological systems through research within three complementary areas: (1) high-throughput genomics and editing, (2) bioinformatics and machine learning, and (3) developmental systems biology. Funding of this proposal will enable up to 12 graduate students from Duke University to engage in research at a partner institution over a three-year period. Participating students will travel to Berlin for approximately three months in order to engage in research under the mentorship of a host scientist. Students will obtain valuable international experience, significant training in methodology and critical thinking, and career-building experiences at the partner institution, thereby benefitting from expertise at both sites. Students will be co-advised by a dissertation committee including computational and biological experts from both sites. A tailored program will support the students in bridging the three emphasis areas identified above and acquiring important skills to prepare them for future careers at the cutting edge of academia and industry. Students will not only benefit from the advantage of combined physical and human resources, they will gain valuable methodological skills, domain expertise, and experience in critical thinking through a truly collaborative learning and research environment in order to become future leaders in the ongoing transformation of biology into a quantitative discipline, with a long-term impact on how genomics affects numerous aspects of human life.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this IRES project was to train graduate students for future leadership roles in interdisciplinary genome science. Genomic sciences cover a vast range of topics, and this program deliberated focused on experimental and computational approaches to understanding gene regulation to reflect the expertise and experience of the participating faculty mentors in the US and Germany.

The primary objectives of the program were: (1) to broaden technical training for the participating graduate students, including experience with both experimental methodologies and computational approaches, and (2) to foster the development of soft skills in communication, team science, and project leadership. A key component of the program involved embedding students in a laboratory group with complementary skills to that of their primary faculty mentor for several months. This component of the project took advantage of an extended history of close interactions between a core set of lab groups in Berlin, Germany and at Duke University, which allows us to provide strong support and a highly tailored experience for each graduate student. Our aspiration was that graduate students who completed this program would be better equipped to develop into independent, interdisciplinary researchers who combine deep knowledge of genome biology with cutting-edge experimental and computational training and the ability to lead productive interdisciplinary research teams of their own.

 The primary activities of the project were three-fold. (1) A weekly journal club. Meetings took place every other Thursday at 9:00AM local time, 3:00PM German time in order to maximize attendance despite the 6-hour time difference between Germany and the East coast of the US. In order to encourage participation, meetings were held when semesters were in session at both locations (about 8 months out of the year). During each session, a graduate student presented a recent research publication and led a subsequent discussion. (2) An annual retreat. The format primarily consisted of oral presentation by participating graduate students, who discussed their research projects. In addition, there were a few presentations by faculty. The original intent was that these retreats would be held in-person, but this was only possible during year 3 of funding, as discussed below. The retreats also featured social events for the graduate students and faculty mentors to get to know each other. (3) Individual research visits. Mentioned earlier, these were envisioned as 1-3 month visits to Berlin, where the graduate student would be hosted by a partner research group. During this visit, the student would receive technical training complementary to that available in their home lab in North Carolina. This visit would also allow the student to expand their communication and managerial skills, expand their professional network, and gain the valuable experience of working in a foreign country.    

The COVID-19 pandemic, which began about half-way through the first year of funding for this project, had a major impact on our ability to achieve outcomes. The objectives of this project depended heavily on international travel, which was simply not possible for most of the funding period due to travel restrictions in the US and Germany. The journal club was envisioned as a virtual event from the outset, and was not affected. The annual retreats were partially affected: the first two were virtual events and the third was held at Duke University, with many graduate students and two faculty from Berlin traveling in-person and several others participating virtually. Finally, the in-person visits were by far the most affected by travel restrictions: just a few students were able to complete visits. 

Despite the inability to organize in-person research visits, the other objectives were largely achieved. In particular, graduate students expanded their technical training, developed their soft skills, and grew their professional networks.
